1111023189096886273.text: Plasma Debit: Plasma Cash where coins are functionally bidirectional payment channels between users and operator. "Channel transactions" are instant, & a "Plasma transaction" is now akin to transferring ownership of a channel from A to B: https://ethresear.ch/t/plasma-debit-arbitrary-denomination-payments-in-plasma-cash/2198 … @danrobinson  (9)

1111023188421558272.text: Speed: Can we get instant/faster transactions, i.e., without waiting for a mainchain txn to be confirmed? We can — by incorporating channel-esque mechanisms, i.e., have capital locked up and made directly available for transacting. Two examples of such hybrid models: (8/x)

1111023187163336710.text:
...one problem tho: as ranges split, proof data size starts growing again. "Defragmentation," i.e., recombining ranges (sort-of-but-not-really-at-all-like "channel rebalancing" in lightning) is an open area of research / experimentation:
https://ethresear.ch/t/plasma-cash-defragmentation-take-3/3737 …
(7/x)

1111023186378919939.text:
Range payments: Plasma cash rethunk: very small coins, and transactions spend across whole ranges of coins instead of just transferring them one at a time. This effectively rescues fungibility:
https://medium.com/plasma-group/plasma-spec-9d98d0f2fccf … @ben_chain 
(6/x)

1111023184516706304.text:
Checkpoints: every two weeks (or whatever), with some coordination, we can checkpoint a bunch of plasma coins; once finalized, all prior data can be discarded. Checkpoint txn can get large, but easy to optimize:
https://ethresear.ch/t/plasma-xt-plasma-cash-with-much-less-per-user-data-checking/1926 … @kelvinfichter
(4/x)

1111023183753297922.text:
Plasma Cash: Use non-fungible tokens on Plasma chain; now no more mass exit problem & users need only validate data that concerns them (light clients). Still requires storing some data per plasma block (also, we lost fungibility, :/ ) https://github.com/loomnetwork/plasma-paper/blob/master/plasma_cash.pdf … @gakonst
(3/x)

1111023182981550080.text:
Minimum viable plasma: Very minimum viable. Bitcoin-esque UTXO transactions only; requires all users to validate everything, and if the operator misbehaves, all users have a time-limit before which they must exit ("mass exits"):
https://ethresear.ch/t/minimal-viable-plasma/426 … @VitalikButerin
(2/x)

1111023182310453250.text: To start: what even is Plasma? Debatable! I vote for: "A trustless layer 2 mechanism in which an arbitrary # of transactions can be finalized with a single, constant-sized on chain commit + some off chain data, with no additional trust/ data availability assumptions." (1/x)

1076188823728648192.text: I'd also add: much of the biggest challenges arise from trying to scale P2P payments broadly; if we restrict scope to application specific state channels, things are easier and the tools are actually closer to ready than most probably realize IMO (maybe that's for another thread)

1076188822923292674.text: Much of this is an over-simplification; this is mostly meant for newcomers who have been hit with the hype but aren't yet familiar with the critiques; consider it part of an effort to cut through some of the "bcore is evil no bcash is a scam" noise

1076188822369640448.text: ... Joe's software is basically making financial decisions for him, which is likely to make Joe uneasy.

1076188821635649536.text: UX: particularly tough in LN (and let's be real, we're already not exactly the masters of UX here in crypto land). Deciding when/why to open and close channels is pretty complex/abstract for "average Joe consumer." We can try to abstract those details away from Joe, but then...

1076188820910080000.text: If a miner (/miner cartel) censors you... on layer 1, you can't make a payment, which is annoying... on layer 2, you can't close your channel, which means you could actually lose your money, which is far more annoying (h/t @VladZamfir)

1076188820247379973.text: Miner censorship (controversial): if miners can censor you, that's bad no matter which layer you're chilling on, but worse on layer 2:

1076188819576229888.text: Again, hot wallet risks can be mitigated, but cold storage is basically off the table, and nothing beats good ole cold storage.

1076188818758352897.text: Hot wallets: if you want to receive payments, you'll probably want a hot wallet, and if you're gonna route payments, you basically need one. The history of crypto exchanges is a long, sad, history of proving that hot wallets are dangerous.

1076188817953095680.text: Furthermore: there'll always be trade-offs between "making routing work better" and preserving privacy. I.e., routing wants you to advertise as much of your state as possible, privacy wants you to not do that. Can't have it both ways (h/t @JorgeStolfi)

1076188817198104576.text: ... (channel balances change, nodes go in & out of liveness, channels open and close on the ledger, etc.) This is a boring old P2P networking problem and there's nothing inherently impossible here, but it'll require lots of infrastructure that'll have to keep evolving.

1076188816447361024.text: Routing: even cryptoeconmic/game-theoretical/mechanistic-design-contraints aside, the practical matter of how to find / communicate the state of available routes is tough given how distributed the state is and how many ways it keeps changing...

1076188815688126464.text: Of course, if a route is unavailable, she can always open up a new channel, but how often will she have to do so? If it's, say, 1 in 40 payments, then there's your scaling ceiling right there: 40x.

1076188814975082497.text: Liquidity: if A wants to pay 1 BTC to B , and A doesn't have a channel open with B (which is most likely), A has to "route" her payment through X, Y, Z, etc. This means A needs to find routers X, Y, and Z that all have at least 1 BTC in their channels, otherwise she can't pay.

1076188814413045761.text: "You could lose your money if your internet goes down long enough" is a pretty heavy burden for a consumer to accept.

1076188813695897600.text: ... need to entail running a full node, you only have to be live ever-so-often, perhaps planned "breaks" so you can go backpacking, etc. — but unless you trust a third party (watchtower) you can't eliminate the liveness requirement entirely.

1076188811758059520.text: Liveness: in short, if you want to *receive* funds and not just send them, then you need to maintain some degree of internet access; otherwise (for all you know) your funds could be gone. You can mitigate the liveness requirement various ways — i.e., being "live" doesn't ...
